The Chapter with Kaccāyana
Mahākappinatthera’s Birth Story
“The Victor called Padumuttara,
who had gone to the far shore of all things,

analyzed: u t itaḥ a jaṭā kāse
translated: was proclaimed in the open space of Aṭṭhaka,
like the sun in the autumn sky.
He inspired with the radiance of his words,
the lotuses to be trained;
he dried up the mud of defilements,
with the rays of his mind, the leader.
He destroyed the fame of the sectarians,
like the sun destroys the glow of the stars;
he revealed the radiance of the truth,
like the sun reveals the jewel.
He was the future of the qualities,
like the ocean is of the jewels;
like Pajjunna rains down on beings,
he rained down the cloud of the Dhamma.
At that time I was a gambler,
in the city called Haṁsasavhaya;
I approached and listened to the Dhamma,
like a bird to the sound of the water.
To the monk who was the teacher,
the disciple who had done what was to be done;
as he was revealing his qualities,
my mind was satisfied.
Having heard, I was pleased and happy,
having invited the Realised One;
having fed him,
I aspired to that state.
At that time I was the same as a swan,
with the voice of a goose and a drum,
‘Look at this great minister,
skilled in making decisions.
He has fallen at my feet,
with his body hair standing on end;
Dark-green in colour, with full flesh,
with a clear face and eyes.
Surrounded by a great retinue,
fit for a king, of great fame;
This one, having done what should be done,
hopes with a joyful heart.
Through this act of worship,
through this offering and these aspirations,
For a hundred thousand aeons
he will not be reborn in a bad destination.
Among the gods he will be the most beautiful,
among humans the greatest;
Having experienced this remainder,
he will attain Nibbāna.
After a hundred thousand aeons,
born in the family of the crows,
with the clan name Gotama,
he will be a teacher in the world.
He will be an heir to his teachings,
born from the heart of the Dhamma;
with the name Kappina,
he will be a disciple of the Teacher.’
Then I, having done what should be done,
in the Dispensation of the Victor,
having given up my human body,
went to the Tusita (heaven).
Having ruled over divine and human kingdoms,
a hundred times,
I was born near Bārāṇasī,
in the Kaniyaja clan.
I had a retinue of a thousand,
and I was married to my wife;
I served five hundred paccekabuddhas,
with a retinue of five hundred.
After feeding them for three months,
afterwards I gave them three robes;
Then we all died,
and we were reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
Then we all were reborn as humans,
after death we were reborn
in the city of Kukkuṭa,
in front of the Himalayas.
I was called Kappina,
the son of a king, of great fame;
The rest were born in the families of the poor,
and they surrounded me.
I attained the happiness of a great king,
with all my desires fulfilled;
I heard of the arising of the Buddha,
announced by merchants.
‘The Buddha has arisen in the world,
the incomparable, the only one;
He reveals the true Dhamma,
the deathless, the supreme happiness.
His disciples are well-concentrated,
well-liberated, and without defilements’;
Having heard their good words,
I honoured the merchants.
I renounced the kingdom with my wife,
and left, devoted to the Buddha;

analyzed: nadim disvā mahā canda  pūritam samatittika  appatiṭṭham an ālamba
translated: full to the brim,🔽unfordable, without a support,
difficult to cross, flowing swiftly;
Remembering the Buddha’s qualities,
I safely crossed over.
If the Buddha, the one who has crossed the flood,
the one who has gone to the end of the world, the wise one,
By this declaration of the truth,
may my going be successful.
If there is a path to the other side,
a freedom that is a lasting happiness;
By this declaration of the truth,
may my going be successful.
If the Sangha, which has crossed the flood,
is the unsurpassed field of merit;
By this declaration of the truth,
may my going be successful.’
As soon as he had spoken this declaration of the truth,
the water on the path disappeared.
Then with ease I crossed over,
to the delightful bank of the river.
I saw the Buddha sitting there,🔽like the rising sun,
like a burning flame of gold,
like a shining beacon tree.
Like the moon surrounded by stars,
with his disciples in front,
like Vāsava raining,
with the rain of the Teaching.
After paying homage with my friends,
I sat down to one side;
Then, knowing our disposition,
The Buddha taught the Dhamma.
Having heard the stainless Dhamma,
We spoke to the Victor:
‘Great Hero, ordain us,
We are disgusted with existence.’
‘The Dhamma is well-expounded, monks,
For the cessation of suffering;
Live the spiritual life,’
Thus spoke the seventh Buddha.
Together with that speech,
We all became monks;
We were fully ordained,
And stream-enterers in the dispensation.
Then, going to Jeta’s Wood,
The Guide instructed us;
Instructed by the Victor,
I attained perfection.
Then, a thousand monks,
I instructed at that time;
Those who followed my instruction,
They too were without pollutants.
The Victor, pleased with that quality,
Established me in this foremost position:
‘Foremost among those who instruct the monks,
Worthy of offerings from the great people.’
A hundred thousand deeds were done,
The fruit was shown to me here;
Like one released from a flood,
I burnt up my pollutants.
I have burned up the defilements,
I live without defilements.
How welcome it was for me
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.
